Divorce, while permitted in certain circumstances, does not grant the right to enter into a new marriage without committing adultery. It is crucial to uphold the sanctity of marriage and understand the original intention of divorce as a means to protect the innocent party. By preserving the high ideal of marriage, we can ensure the welfare of society and uphold the teachings of Christ.

However, if the divorce is justified by fornication or other forms of sexual misconduct, the innocent party may be allowed to marry again. The initial intent of divorce was to protect the innocent party from being bound to an unfaithful spouse. It is important to uphold the high ideal of marriage, for it forms the foundation of society's morality and the well-being of humanity. Let us not misuse the concept of divorce but approach it with the utmost care and understanding of its intended purpose.
